column1: You may need surgery for a diabetes complication or for some other problem that is unrelated to your diabetes.
Your diabetes may increase your risk for problems during or after your surgery, such as: - Infection after surgery - Healing slower - Heart problems
Sometimes, it can be stopped 48 hours before and 48 hours after surgery to decrease the risk of lactic acidosis.
So talk to your doctor about your diabetes control and any complications you have from diabetes.
Tell your doctor about any problems you have with your heart, kidneys, or eyes, or if you have loss of feeling in your feet.
During surgery, insulin is given by the anesthesiologist.

You may have more trouble controlling because you: - Have trouble eating - Are vomiting - Are stressed after surgery - Are less active than usual - Have pain or discomfort Expect that you may take more time to heal because of your diabetes.
